title: Chapter 1 - Chemicals
summary_bullets: Matter is made of elements composed of atoms.
Atoms combine to form molecules and compounds.
Chemical reactions rearrange atoms via bonds forming and breaking.
Ions form by loss or gain of electrons; electrolytes are important in body fluids.
Acids, bases, and buffers influence pH; homeostasis maintains near‑neutral pH.
Organic molecules (carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, nucleic acids) are carbon‑based; water and salts are inorganic.

elements_atoms.title: 1.2 Elements and Atoms
elements_atoms.markdown:
- Elements are pure substances of one kind of atom.
- Atoms have protons, neutrons, and electrons.
- Atomic number = protons; mass number = protons + neutrons.

molecules_compounds.title: 1.3 Compounds and Molecules
molecules_compounds.markdown:
- Molecules are atoms joined by bonds.
- Compounds contain two or more different elements.
- Covalent vs. ionic bonding; hydrogen bonds in water.

chemical_reactions.title: 1.4 Chemical Reactions
chemical_reactions.markdown:
- Synthesis (A+B→AB), decomposition (AB→A+B), exchange (AB+CD→AD+CB).
- Enzymes speed reactions; temperature and pH affect rates.

ionization.title: 1.5 Ionization
ionization.markdown:
- Ions carry charge in solution.
- Electrolytes conduct current and are vital for nerve/muscle function.

organic_inorganic.title: 1.6 Organic and Inorganic Compounds
organic_inorganic.markdown:
- Water: solvent, temperature buffer.
- Salts: sources of ions.
- Organic classes: carbs (energy), lipids (membranes/energy), proteins (structure/enzymes), nucleic acids (genetic info).

title: Chapter 2 - Classification
summary_bullets: Animal classification groups organisms by shared characteristics.
Vertebrates include fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals.
Mammals are subdivided into monotremes, marsupials, and placentals.
Taxonomic ranks: Kingdom → Phylum → Class → Order → Family → Genus → Species.
Species are groups that interbreed to produce fertile offspring.

vertebrate_classes.title: 2.6 The Classification of Vertebrates
vertebrate_classes.markdown:
- Five classes: fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, mammals.
- Mammalia includes monotremes, marsupials, and placentals.

taxonomy_hierarchy.title: 2.x Taxonomic Ranks
taxonomy_hierarchy.markdown:
- Kingdom → Phylum → Class → Order → Family → Genus → Species.
- Mnemonics can help remember the order.

species_breeds.title: 2.x Species and Breeds
species_breeds.markdown:
- Species can interbreed and produce fertile offspring.
- Breeds/varieties exist within a species (e.g., dog breeds).

title: Chapter 3 - The Cell
summary_bullets: Cells have three main parts: plasma membrane, cytoplasm, and nucleus.
Substances cross the membrane by diffusion, osmosis, active transport, phagocytosis, pinocytosis, and exocytosis.
Osmosis is the diffusion of water across a semi-permeable membrane.
Cytoplasm contains cytosol, inclusions, and organelles such as ribosomes, ER, mitochondria, Golgi bodies, and lysosomes.
The nucleus controls cell activity and contains DNA chromosomes.
Cells divide by mitosis and meiosis.
The cell can be compared to a factory, where each organelle has a specific function.

figures.caption: Diagram 3.1: A variety of animal cells

cell_structure.title: 3.2 The Cell
cell_structure.markdown:
- The cell is the basic unit of life.
- Most cells are microscopic; the ostrich egg is an exception.
- Main parts: plasma membrane, cytoplasm, nucleus.

plasma_membrane.title: 3.3 The Plasma Membrane
plasma_membrane.markdown:
- Separates cell contents from surroundings.
- Made of a phospholipid bilayer with embedded proteins.
- Controls what enters and leaves the cell.

diffusion.title: 3.3.1 Diffusion
diffusion.markdown:
- Molecules move from high to low concentration.
- Passive process; no energy required.
- Important for O₂, CO₂, and nutrient exchange.

osmosis.title: 3.3.1 Osmosis
osmosis.markdown:
- Diffusion of water across a semi-permeable membrane.
- Water moves from dilute to concentrated side.
- Important in cell water balance and kidneys.

tonicity.title: 3.3.1 Tonicity and Red Blood Cells
tonicity.markdown:
- Hypotonic: water enters cell → may burst (haemolysis).
- Hypertonic: water leaves cell → shrinks.
- Isotonic: no net movement (normal saline).

active_transport.title: 3.3.1 Active Transport
active_transport.markdown:
- Moves substances against concentration gradient.
- Requires energy (ATP).
- Maintains Na⁺/K⁺ balance in nerve cells.

phagocytosis.title: 3.3.1 Phagocytosis
phagocytosis.markdown:
- 'Cell eating' — engulfing solid particles like bacteria.
- Uses energy; vital for white blood cell defense.

pinocytosis.title: 3.3.1 Pinocytosis
pinocytosis.markdown:
- 'Cell drinking' — intake of fluids.
- Common in most cells.

exocytosis.title: 3.3.1 Exocytosis
exocytosis.markdown:
- Substances leave the cell via vesicles.
- Used by secretory and nerve cells.

cytoplasm.title: 3.4 The Cytoplasm
cytoplasm.markdown:
- Jelly-like cytosol with inclusions and organelles.
- Site of many cellular reactions.

ribosomes.title: Ribosomes
ribosomes.markdown:
- Tiny organelles that make proteins.
- Found free in cytoplasm or on rough ER.

endoplasmic_reticulum.title: Endoplasmic Reticulum
endoplasmic_reticulum.markdown:
- Network of membranes from nucleus to plasma membrane.
- Smooth ER makes fats; rough ER (with ribosomes) makes proteins.

mitochondria.title: Mitochondria
mitochondria.markdown:
- Powerhouses of the cell.
- Site of cellular respiration (glucose + oxygen → CO₂ + water + energy).

golgi.title: Golgi Apparatus
golgi.markdown:
- Modifies and packages proteins and fats.
- Forms vesicles for transport or secretion.

lysosomes.title: Lysosomes
lysosomes.markdown:
- Contain enzymes to digest bacteria, debris, and old organelles.
- Important for cell cleanup and recycling.

microtubules.title: Microfilaments and Microtubules
microtubules.markdown:
- Responsible for cell shape and movement.
- Form cilia, flagella, and centrioles used in cell division.

nucleus.title: 3.5 The Nucleus
nucleus.markdown:
- Largest structure in the cell.
- Controls activity and contains DNA.
- Surrounded by double membrane with pores.
- Contains nucleoli for ribosome production.

chromosomes.title: 3.5.1 Chromosomes
chromosomes.markdown:
- Contain DNA and control cell activity.
- Visible when cell divides.
- Constant number per species (e.g., humans 46).

cell_division.title: 3.6 Cell Division
cell_division.markdown:
- Mitosis: produces identical cells for growth and repair.
- Meiosis: produces gametes with half the chromosomes.

cell_factory.title: 3.7 The Cell as a Factory
cell_factory.markdown:
- Nucleus = director
- Mitochondria = power supply
- Ribosomes = product makers
- Golgi = packaging
- ER = transport
- Lysosomes = waste disposal
- Membrane = factory wall and gates

title: Chapter 4 - Body Organisation
summary_bullets: Four basic tissues: epithelial, connective, muscle, nervous.
Organs are built from tissues; organs form systems to perform body functions.
Main body cavities: thoracic and abdominal; pleural and pericardial spaces in thorax.
There are 11 major body systems.
Homeostasis maintains a stable internal environment; directional terms describe location.

mrs_gren.title: 4.2 The Organisation of Animal Bodies
mrs_gren.markdown:
- The seven life processes: Movement, Respiration, Sensitivity, Growth, Reproduction, Excretion, Nutrition.
- Cells → Tissues → Organs → Systems.

epithelia_types.title: 4.2.1 Epithelial Tissues
epithelia_types.markdown:
- Simple squamous: diffusion surfaces (alveoli, vessels).
- Cuboidal: kidney tubules (transport).
- Columnar: gut lining (absorption); ciliated columnar: respiratory tract, uterus.

body_cavities.title: 4.4 Body Cavities
body_cavities.markdown: - Thoracic vs abdominal; pleural and pericardial cavities within thorax.

eleven_systems.title: 4.7.1 The 11 Body Systems
eleven_systems.markdown: - Skin, Skeletal, Muscular, Cardiovascular, Lymphatic, Respiratory, Digestive, Urinary, Reproductive, Nervous, Endocrine.

title: Chapter 5 - The Skin
summary_bullets: Skin is the largest organ; epidermis and dermis perform protection and regulation.
Keratin in epidermal cells provides waterproofing and durability.
Keratin structures include hair, feathers, nails/claws/hoofs/horns; antlers are bony.
Skin houses glands (sweat, scent, preen, mammary) and sensory receptors.
Skin regulates body temperature and can synthesize vitamin D.

overview.title: 5.2 The Skin
overview.markdown:
- Two layers: epidermis (avascular, keratinized) and dermis (vascular, connective tissues).
- Variations across vertebrates (hair, feathers, scales).

temperature_control.title: 5.x Temperature Regulation
temperature_control.markdown: - Vasodilation/vasoconstriction; sweating or panting; insulation via hair/feathers.

accessory_structures.title: 5.x Accessory Structures
accessory_structures.markdown: - Hair/feathers; nails/claws/hoofs; glands (sweat, scent, preen, mammary).

title: Chapter 6 - The Skeletal System
summary_bullets: Bones provide support, protection, and leverage for movement; joints allow motion.
Bone tissue remodels and stores minerals; marrow makes blood cells.
Axial skeleton includes skull, vertebral column, rib cage; appendicular includes limbs and girdles.

bone_tissue.title: 6.x Bone Tissue
bone_tissue.markdown: - Compact vs spongy bone; osteons; osteoblasts/osteoclasts remodel bone.

joints.title: 6.x Joints
joints.markdown: - Fibrous, cartilaginous, synovial; range of motion depends on joint type.

title: Chapter 7 - The Muscular System
summary_bullets: Three muscle types: skeletal, cardiac, smooth.
Sliding filament mechanism uses actin and myosin with ATP and calcium.
Muscles act across joints; origin, insertion, agonist/antagonist pairs.

muscle_types.title: 7.x Muscle Types
muscle_types.markdown:
- Skeletal: voluntary, striated.
- Cardiac: heart, intercalated discs.
- Smooth: viscera, involuntary.

contraction.title: 7.x Contraction Basics
contraction.markdown: - Action potentials trigger Ca²⁺ release; actin–myosin cross-bridge cycling produces force.

title: Chapter 8 - The Cardiovascular System
summary_bullets: Heart pumps blood through pulmonary and systemic circuits.
Arteries, capillaries, veins form the vascular network for transport.
Blood carries gases, nutrients, wastes, hormones; pressure and flow are regulated.

heart_overview.title: 8.x Heart Overview
heart_overview.markdown: - Chambers and valves; cardiac cycle; conduction system (SA → AV → Purkinje).

title: Chapter 9 - The Respiratory System
summary_bullets: Ventilation moves air; gas exchange occurs across alveoli.
Oxygen diffuses into blood; carbon dioxide diffuses into alveoli to be exhaled.
Airway anatomy: nose → pharynx → larynx → trachea → bronchi → bronchioles → alveoli.

gas_exchange.title: 9.3/9.4 Gas Exchange
gas_exchange.markdown:
- Narrow capillaries slow blood and press RBCs to walls, aiding O₂ diffusion.
- CO₂ travels mainly as bicarbonate; diffuses into alveoli and is exhaled.

air_passages.title: 9.5 The Air Passages
air_passages.markdown: - Air path and functions of each segment; epiglottis prevents food entering trachea.

title: Chapter 10 - The Lymphatic System
summary_bullets: Lymph forms from tissue fluid and returns to blood via lymph vessels.
Lymph nodes filter lymph and house lymphocytes.
Other organs: spleen, thymus, bone marrow, and lymph nodules (e.g., Peyer’s patches).

lymph_basics.title: 10.2 Lymphatic System
lymph_basics.markdown:
- Lymph = tissue fluid in lymphatic capillaries; contains lymphocytes, proteins, debris.
- Vessels resemble veins and have valves; muscle contractions move lymph.

organs.title: 10.3 Other Organs
organs.markdown:
- Spleen: lymphocyte production, RBC recycling, blood store.
- Thymus: processes lymphocytes.
- Bone marrow and lymph nodules (Peyer’s patches, tonsils).

title: Chapter 11 - The Digestive System
summary_bullets: Digestive tract processes: ingestion, propulsion, digestion, absorption, elimination.
Accessory organs (liver, pancreas) aid digestion and absorption.
Epiglottis prevents food entering trachea; peristalsis moves food along.

alimentary_path.title: 11.x Alimentary Canal
alimentary_path.markdown: - Mouth → pharynx → oesophagus → stomach → small intestine → large intestine → rectum.

title: Chapter 12 - The Urinary System
summary_bullets: Kidneys regulate water, salts, and acid–base balance; birds lack a bladder.
Homeostasis maintains internal constancy; hypothalamus and hormones coordinate thirst and urine concentration.
Body water is ~60–80%; about two‑thirds is intracellular; the rest is extracellular (tissue fluid, blood, lymph).

homeostasis.title: 12.2 Homeostasis
homeostasis.markdown: - Internal conditions must stay within narrow limits; multiple organs contribute (skin, lungs, liver/pancreas, kidneys).

water_distribution.title: 12.3 Water in the Body
water_distribution.markdown: - Total body water high; split between intracellular and extracellular compartments.

maintaining_balance.title: 12.4 Maintaining Water Balance
maintaining_balance.markdown:
- Losses via skin, lungs, feces, urine are matched by intake and metabolic water.
- Hypothalamus triggers thirst; kidneys adjust urine concentration (hormonal control).

title: Chapter 13 - The Reproductive System
summary_bullets: Gametes are produced by meiosis in testes and ovaries; fertilisation forms a zygote.
Male system: testes produce sperm; ducts and glands form semen and deliver it.
Female system: ovaries produce ova and hormones; uterus supports development.
Oestrous cycles vary by species; hormones coordinate ovulation and receptivity.
Mammary glands produce milk; colostrum supplies antibodies.

ovarian_cycle.title: 13.6.2 The Ovarian Cycle
ovarian_cycle.markdown: - Follicle matures and ovulates; corpus luteum secretes progesterone; regresses if no pregnancy.

oestrous_cycle.title: 13.6.4 The Oestrous Cycle
oestrous_cycle.markdown: - FSH stimulates follicles → oestrogen; LH surge triggers ovulation; progesterone prepares uterus; cycles repeat if no pregnancy.

milk_production.title: 13.10 Milk Production
milk_production.markdown: - Prolactin stimulates milk; oxytocin causes let‑down; colostrum rich in antibodies; milk composition varies by species.

title: Chapter 14 - The Nervous System
summary_bullets: Central nervous system: brain and spinal cord; peripheral nerves carry signals.
Forebrain (cerebral hemispheres, hypothalamus), brainstem, and cerebellum have distinct roles.
Hypothalamus links nervous and endocrine systems and supports homeostasis.

brain_overview.title: 14.x The Brain
brain_overview.markdown:
- Cerebral cortex handles sensory perception, memory, voluntary movement.
- Hypothalamus controls autonomic functions and hormone release; pituitary lies below.

title: Chapter 15 - The Senses
summary_bullets: Special senses include smell, taste, sight; proprioceptors sense limb position.
Olfactory organ detects airborne chemicals; taste buds detect dissolved chemicals.
The eye’s sclera, choroid, and retina enable vision; rods sense dim light, cones sense color and detail.

smell.title: 15.7 Smell
smell.markdown: - Olfactory hairs in nasal epithelium detect molecules; impulses travel via olfactory nerve to brain.

taste.title: 15.8 Taste
taste.markdown: - Taste buds on tongue contain receptor cells; four basic tastes in humans.

sight.title: 15.9 Sight
sight.markdown: - Sclera (protection), choroid (vascular, pigmented), retina (rods and cones); lens accommodates for focus.

title: Chapter 16 - The Endocrine System
summary_bullets: Endocrine glands secrete hormones into blood to regulate longer‑term processes.
Pituitary and hypothalamus integrate nervous and endocrine control.
Thyroid, parathyroids, adrenals, pancreas, ovaries, and testes have key hormonal roles.

endocrine_basics.title: 16.3 Endocrine Glands and Hormones
endocrine_basics.markdown: - Ductless glands release hormones to blood; target organs recognize specific hormones.

pituitary_hypothalamus.title: 16.4 The Pituitary Gland and Hypothalamus
pituitary_hypothalamus.markdown: - Pituitary (anterior/posterior) controlled by hypothalamus; secretes GH, prolactin, FSH, LH, etc.

thyroid_parathyroid.title: 16.6–16.7 Thyroid and Parathyroids
thyroid_parathyroid.markdown:
- Thyroxine regulates growth/metabolism; iodine deficiency → goitre.
- Parathormone regulates blood calcium and phosphate excretion.

pancreas_ovaries_testes.title: 16.9–16.11 Pancreas, Ovaries, Testes
pancreas_ovaries_testes.markdown:
- Pancreatic islets secrete insulin (blood glucose control).
- Ovaries secrete oestrogen and progesterone; testes secrete testosterone.
